cpmeister
cpmeister

replies.bodyText: i will change to map. but just for my understanding / learning - what is the advantage of using Map here?  compiler will probably replace Map with EnumMap at build time or?
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText:
Generally you want your code to define behavior without being beholden to any particular concrete implementation. That is why you should interact with List, Set, Map, or Collection instead of ArrayList, LinkedList, HashMap, etc...
Interacting with interfaces does a better job of displaying the code's intent without getting bogged down with the concrete implementations of your data structures.
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: ok. understood. no optimisation but improving readability and best practice.
replies.author: yfre

timeline.bodyText: When do you plan to implement this?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
Im not sure what is the best approach here from the user perspective.
currently the temperature units (C/F) can be set at binding settings level. one can change the temperature units in the binding configuration and this will apply to all thermostats and coolers/heaters.
however, in home app one can change the temperature units for each accessory independently.
to implement this i see 2 options


a new openHAB item to store temperature units (as part of accessory group)


handle units internally in accessory class. i.e. one can change it from home app but not from openHAB


sounds too much to me. we have already a lot of items for different characteristics. and that one is probably one nobody needs.


does not sounds like a proper solution as one cannot change units from openHAB


the current solution - global setting is imho the best one.
how you see it? what is the approach in other bindings?
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: I would vote for global setting.
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: ok. global settings are already working. i removed TODO here.
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: to me it looks like "covertToCelsius" makes already use of QuantityType (AbstractHomekitAccessoryImpl.convertAndRound)
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText:
I'm just concerned that getStateAs would end up converting a QuantityType into a DecimalType thus losing access to the units field.
Is it guaranteed that all of the items you are tracking are using the same units determined in getSettings()? What if the settings change?
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
currently we are using temperature (and conversion from C to F) in thermostat, temperature sensor and with this PR also in HeaterCooler. they all are using the same method.
you are right, the QuantityType gets lost and also settings change will not get propagated to the items and to the home app. the other direction will also not work, i.e. change of units in home app will have no impact on OH settings. So, basically the current code does not support changes of temperature units at runtime.
it needs to fix. but i would suggest to make a separate enhancement & PR for this and fix it for all 3 accessories with temperature units.
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: I agree, it should be done in another PR.
replies.author: cpmeister
